newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela TEM demand been higher than supply - Casas.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela TEM demand been higher than supply - Casas.

text.p: Demand for Venezuelan Central Bank short term securities, called TEMs, has been higher than the supply, which has helped push down interest rates, Central Bank president Antonio Casas Gonzalez said.
"We haven't been able to offer more...due to the losses they bring the Central Bank," Casas told the Senate Finance Commission.
TEMs are issued by the Central Bank in open market operations and, unlike most countries where government backed Treasury bills are used, are financed by the Central Bank.
Yields on six month TEMs, which act as a benchmark for wider interest rates, fell two basis points in Wednesday's regular auction to 14.33 percent on high bolivar liquidity, TEM traders said.
Casas added that last week's uncharacteristic volatility of the bolivar had in part been due to low interest rates, "but also the general economic panorama."
Last week was marked by persistent rumors of coups, President Rafael Caldera's failing health and investor concern about rising inflation on the back of a 75 percent average public pay wage increase.
But Casas re-iterated the current foreign exchange bands system would not be changed.
"We think they proved successful in 1996 and also in the first months of this year," he said. "We'll keep the bands as they have been established."
